With an unsealed bungalow and no heat, we cowered under the blanket. Showering outside was also a frigid experience – balancing the fluctuating water temperature with the cool air made for a quick turn around. Once we were cleaned up and appropriately dressed, we hopped on the bike to head into town and find some breakfast. We ended up eating an over-priced, mediocre Western-style breakfast before regrouping about plans for the day on the porch of our bungalow.

We decided we’d take the bike out in the late morning, explore the countryside a bit more, and hit some of Pai’s highlights. Sitting in the midst of a tall hill opposite of our back porch sat a towering, pure-white seated Buddha. We thought finding the road to that landmark would be a good way to kick-off the day, so off we went.

One thing I should note is that in Thailand, people drive on the left side of the road (opposite from what we’re used to in the U.S.). So given that we were still green motor bikers plus Aaron had to constantly remember which side of the road to drive on, we made up a song whenever we got on the bike to remind us where to drive. It was simple… basically me singing “Stay on the right side of the road… of the road…” to the tune of “Let it Go” from Frozen. I blame my niece Avery for the Frozen influence.

Song belting, the little bike zoomed around corners, passed vast open fields of green and brown, under a partially shaded roadway. The temperature was perfect on the bike with the wind in our faces. If I closed my eyes, it could be summer in Seattle, such a funny feeling. When we determined we could ride no further up to the Buddha, we parked the bike, looped our helmets around the handle bars, and started trekking up stairs. A lot of stairs.

At the top of the 200+ stairs, we found a shrine, a bell tower and an lookout spot. We walked around the corner of one of the buildings when the Buddha finally came into view. The catch? It was up another set of at least 100 stairs. Blergh.

As we climbed higher and higher, the view behind us grew more and more spectacular, overlooking the sleepy farmland below. The platform on which the Buddha was seated was nearly empty. We removed our shoes before stepping up the final step, and saw we were sharing this experience with one other traveler, a monk in orange, the monk’s friend, and handicapped boy sitting in the corner with a donation box.

The Buddha was massive but up-close not quite as pristine as it looked seated on the hillside from afar. It was white but weathered, a chunk of its headpiece had fallen off and was seated in the corner of the platform, the replacement piece didn’t quite match. But all the same, I have an affinity for the peace the seated Buddhas exude and enjoyed the visit.

We drank in the lovely view one last time before descending the stairs. Next stop, the bridge in town that was originally built during the Japanese occupation. We headed back down into the valley below, winding past a few elephant camps, luxury hotels, and homestays out in the countryside. We crossed the bridge built beside the Japanese bridge that vehicles use, pulled off to the side of the road that was lined with tourist vendors, and walked toward the wooden and metal structure. The view from the bridge was really nice – it overlooked soft-peaked hills, farmland, and a low-flowing river.

We watch cars fly by on the motor bridge and noticed that as we drove over the bridge, it was painted a nice white. But as we walked next to the motorist bridge, its sides facing away from drivers, were a mess of dripping dried paint. Someone didn’t think it was worth it to actually paint the whole bridge, just what drivers would see. Funny.

After that, we headed to Pai Canyon. We had to take the highway to get there instead of the back roads and were instantly annoyed at all the drivers whizzing by us, passing other cars in a ludicrous fashion, and beeping their horns left and right.

We arrived and trekked up paved stairs and a ramp on a hillside until we reached kind of an entryway to the canyon. Even from here, less exposed, the view was a brilliant 360 degrees around. In the distance were hunter green velvet hills, below our feet, a brown dusty canyon unrolled itself. There were several paths from the top of the ramp, so we picked the one that looked like it went the furthest out in the canyon and headed off.

First, we had to scramble down a few feet of packed dirt. This put us on a jutting pathway with dropoffs on both sides. At the other side of this pathway, we had to scramble back up a good fifty feet, using tree roots and plants to aid in getting us up the loose dirt.

Atop this next peak, the real canyon came into view. Pai refers to this as “Thailand’s Grand Canyon,” and while it’s nothing of that magnitude, it was pretty awesome to experience. We were the only two people trekking along the ridges, every way we turned, farmland or mountainous scenery shifted into view.

We walked around for a bit until the sun reemerged from behind some clouds and we decided we should take cover. Scrambling the other way was probably a bit more challenging, but we utilized our rock climbing experience to descend and scale. After our little adventure, we headed back to Pai in search of some lunch. Knowing we wanted to avoid the overpriced Western food, we zigzagged back and forth on a few side streets until we found a little mom and pop shop that looked good.

We ordered pork, rice, and greens dishes and hoped for the best (often times these little joints can be hit or miss). To our utter delight, everything was fresh and flavorful… not to mention much less expensive than other fair in town. Following lunch, we returned to our stoop and relaxed in front of a beautiful pink sunset tucked behind the hills. Not soon after dark the hippie convent started up their music for the evening (they did this all three nights we stayed there). People were belting off-key renditions of Bob Marley and songs people “had written themselves.” The music went until after 1am each night. So much for my quiet evenings.

We dined on bad khao soi that evening and then walked through the night market again. One of our super mean but also very entertaining games we played while in Pai was ‘spot the worst motorbike injury.’ What do you get when you mix Westerners with little-to-no moped experience, cheap transportation, a busy city center, and rough roads? A lot of road rash, bandages, and the occasional sling or crutches. That evening, we mostly spotted leg bandages.

Tour de Pai: Part II

I awoke early the next morning and instead of sitting in bed while Aaron slept, I stole away with a blanket and my computer and parked myself on the chair on the porch. There was a thick fog lying lazily over the fields in front of our bungalow. It was quiet, and introspective, and I quite enjoyed the bite in the fresh air. Aaron joined me an hour or so later and we packed up for the hike to a waterfall we had planned for that morning.

We drove in the opposite direction of town, down an old dirt road. When we reached the start of the hike, that’s when Aaron told me the hike would include switchbacks over the river. And from the looks of the start of the hike, there wouldn’t be a way to do it without getting wet. Grouchy, I did all matter of complaining until Aaron suggested that we just bag it and do something else.

Instead of getting exercise, we opted to eat breakfast at a resort instead. From there, we decided to take a ride further afield and see more of the countryside. This turned out to be a great decision. The scenery up into the hills and through the valleys outside of Pai was stunning. Earthy, raw, light, and gritty. We passed tons of farms, livestock, modest homes, banana tree groves, and crisscrossed over the river, stopping to capture photos along the way.

At one point, we saw what we thought was signage to another waterfall, and followed the rough road up into the hills. For awhile, we thought we were completely off the beaten track. But as we came around few more blind corners on the narrow road, a few homestays came into view. Out of nowhere, a fifty-something year old woman came running toward us making the ‘smoking cigarette’ gesture and yelling “you smoke marijuana?”

We got a huge kick out of this, but knowing Thailand’s harsh drug policies, we obviously declined. When we finally came to the end of the road, we pulled our bike up next to about 25 others and made our way on foot down some muddy steps toward the river. There, we found our collection of waterfalls and a ton of people enjoying them. We scrambled up a boulder to get a better view and watch all the tourists in the chilly river use the worn rocks on one of the waterfalls as a slide that shot them into the deep pool below.

After that, we headed back out on one of the main roads and followed signs to a viewpoint, which ended up being a giant field backed up to a little cliff that had a nice view of the mountains. We decided to skip paying the entry-fee (on principal), and instead scooted out in the middle of the field to relax for a bit. The field was fairly flat, made up of dried grass and dirt. As we took some pictures, including me pretending to man the helm of the bike, Aaron suggested this might be a good place to for me to practice captaining the moped. I was a little hesitant at first, but after some careful instruction from Aaron, I took ahold of the handlebars, swung my leg over, and gently hit the throttle of the surprisingly heavy vehicle.

Zoom, zoom, zoom! I was off. First I tried a straight line, then had Aaron turn the bike around for me, and off I went in the other direction. Then I tried riding the perimeter of the field. The throttle was a little tricky at first, but I started to get the hang of it. Everything was going great until I tried to make too tight of a turn at too slow of a speed and felt the bike tip.

Now, the last time I rode a bike was over a year ago. It was the first time I was trying out a road bike (vs. a mountain bike) and I was trying clip-in shoes at Aaron’s insistence. I got all siked up for the ride, I clipped in, I rolled maybe six inches, then immediately fell over, shoes firmly attached to the pedals. As you can imagine, this scene ended in tears and me yelling at Aaron… then storming off, refusing to “get back on the horse,” with a bruised leg and ego.

So, when I felt the moped start to tip in the field in Pai, I had an immediate flashback to that bike moment. But in a split-second, I realized my feet needn’t stay in place. I basically bolted from the bike as it fell to the ground, unscathed. I was totally fine, in fact, I thought it was kind of funny. Aaron was immediately concerned and came sprinting toward me, helping me get the bike back up.

He asked if I wanted to take another ride so this wasn’t my last impression of the experience, but I decided against that, not wanting to be those people we were laughing at bandaged up the night before.

From there, we finished our scenic drive and headed back to our lunch joint, from the day before, for some grub.

We reemerged that evening and found ourselves at Na’s, a Thai restaurant in town that’s very popular, and rightfully so. We ended up ordering a bunch of dishes (including the best pad see ew ever, Britta!), enjoyed the flavorful food, and soaked in our last night in northern Thailand.

Travel Day(s)

The next morning, we awoke, packed, checked out of our Airbnb and snagged some tea and scones at a bakery in town. After breakfast, we returned our bike and loaded into our van to make the trek back to Chiang Mai.

The ride was pretty uneventful. Again, we mostly listened to podcasts as the van chugged up the steep curves, and flew down the other side of each hill. We were delivered to the bus station with about three hours of dead time until our train. With that, we found an air conditioned cafe and read our books for a few hours. Before we made it to the train station, we stopped in at a little cafe across the street. Not expecting much from the food, I ordered the dish I always order when I think the food will be mediocre, pad thai. I’ll be damned if that wasn’t the best pad thai I had during our entire stay in Thailand. It was sweet, sour, and saucy, topped with a plethora of bean sprouts. Heaven.

A half hour before our train was scheduled to leave, we gathered up our bags and walked across the street to the station. We then entered what would be home for the next 14 hours… our sleeper train.

I was a little unsure of the experience, but all in all, it was totally fine. In fact, the Thai sleeper trains are much, much nicer than the ones in Vietnam. Aaron and I had a bottom and top soft bunk booked, so we were able to hang out together on the bottom bunk together until we decided to go to sleep.

Across from us (sharing the 4-person alcove) was a Chinese man who had been traveling via ground transport from the middle of China to Bangkok for the past two days (he must have been exhausted) and a Thai who spent most of the waking time hanging out outside of the car.

For our part, Aaron worked on the project while I listened to podcasts and enjoyed the scenery until it grew too dark to see anything. At about 7:30pm, the Chinese man across the way had his bed made up and curtains drew all around him, banishing his seatmate to the top bunk early. Rough!

I watched movies until we decided it was time to take our bunks. We made them up (clean bottom sheets and pillowcases were nicely folded on each bunk, and a fresh blanket was in a sealed plastic bag). We settled in, pulled our curtains and that’s when it started… the snoring. And not just casual, lying on your back or stuffy nose snoring, I mean you must have a sleep disorder and you’re keeping the entire train car awake kind of snoring.

I had just fallen asleep when he started his 10 minute series of snoring (it was like 10 minutes on, 5 minutes off). I woke up annoyed, and put on a movie with headphones to try and drown it out, expecting to fall asleep a few minutes into the film. Fast forward to the credits rolling with my eyes still open and snores still happening… at 2:30am. I felt murderous!

I fell asleep sometimes after that and the 5:30am shake was a rude wakeup call. But we were almost in Bangkok. The train ended up taking another hour and a half from that point in time to actually get to the train station because the traffic was so bad, but when we finally pulled up, grabbed our bags, and zombie walked-out of the station, we realized… it was Christmas Eve!

Up Next: Bangkok does Christmas bigger than the U.S., Aaron squeals with glee on a canal boat commute, and Maya tries not to cry eating spicy food at an all-locals restaurant.

To properly recap our time in Chiang Mai, I must first start with our travels from the Philippines to Thailand. After spending two weeks on the beach on a remote island, Aaron and I found ourselves (dare I say it) beached-out! When our travel day finally came, we kissed our motorbike and surfboards goodbye and hopped on flight one of three that would take us to Thailand.

A short stint in Singapore

Our flight from Siargao to Cebu was fine… we were especially relieved when it left on-time as only one flight a day leaves Siargao, we had a tight layover in Cebu if there was any delay, our flights weren’t booked continuously, AND it was now the rainy season on the island bringing storms and flight cancellations to the little airport with a short runway. But, we left the island on schedule and landed in Cebu with plenty of time to spare. We re-entered the international terminal, picked up our SilkAir tickets, paid our hefty $15/a piece terminal fees (compare that to our ticket price to fly from Siargao to Cebu at ~$25), and we boarded the first jet plane in quite a while, bound for Singapore.

We arrived in Singapore at 8pm and were determined to not purchase a hotel room for the night. Having checked our backpacks through to Chiang Mai, we were traveling light in Singapore and were excited because we had read that the airport offers a free city tour that we wouldn’t need to leave security or customs to go on.

We had heard that the Singapore airport was pretty baller, but as soon as we arrived, we were still surprised. While the boarding areas and long hallways were pretty standard form for any airport, we also noticed huge, digital guides all over the place. At these large touchscreen kiosks, we could view all the food and shopping options, we could request a printout of suggested activities at the airport depending on our interests, and we could get a personalized WiFi access code…impressive. But we made a bee-line to the tour station only to have our hopes crushed as the last tour had left an hour ago and they no longer did night tours.

I was disappointed. I was looking forward to getting out and about in the city (without a ton of effort), plus it would have helped kill time during our 13 hour layover. We recovered by walking around for a bit, checking out different things in our terminal. There was a koi pond, an orchid garden, an outside sunflower garden, a gaming room, a small movie theater, an indoor children’s play structure, free leg massagers, and great views of airplane traffic.

After wandering around for a bit, we tried to find a quieter place to hang, eat the cheapest food we could find (food and drinks were CRAZY expensive in the airport) and watch a movie on our computers…

9:00pm: Watching Star Wars on a set of uncomfortable chairs next to children’s play structure. Cold. Thunderstorms and heavy rain roll in, making it a show on the runways.

10:30pm: Decided we’re tired and look for darker place to rest. Decide on the movie theater and finagle two seats.

12:30am: Aaron wakes me up before the Spongebob movie comes on and looks to seek refuge elsewhere.

12:45am: Walk around like zombies looking for a place to crash… all the obvious places are taken… bodies lay everywhere. Debate about just laying on the floor in a corner somewhere. Oh wait, that corner is taken up too.

1:00am: Decide to follow a sign to a “refuge,” hoping beyond hope that it’s not “for-pay.” Curiosity is rewarded as reclined chairs come into view down a quieter terminal hall. Find seats next to each other (the only two left!) lay back and observe the more seasoned airport sleepers around us that have pillows, blankets, eye masks.

4:30am: Too cold to continue sleeping, decide to reward ourselves with Starbucks and sit out in the humid sunflower garden to warm up as the sun starts to peek up over the horizon.

6:00am: Share a banh mi sando (because it’s to expensive to purchase two).

7:30am: Plane is fully boarded and takes off for Chiang Mai (finally!).

Arrival in Chiang Mai

Our flight almost due-North from Singapore, over Malaysia and southern Thailand was full of pretty cool sights. I took a few pictures and videos including a timelapse of our descent and landing (be warned it was pretty bumpy going through the clouds).

Entry into Thailand as Americans was super easy as we didn’t need visas. Basically, we just zipped through the line, had our photos taken at passport control, and went on our way. We took a cab into the city (luckily our Airbnb host had given us the lowdown on what to expect re: taking a taxi and the price) and we were whisked off to our Airbnb, which was a newly refurbished studio apartment about 15 minutes outside of the old city.

First impressions of Chiang Mai was that it was a smaller city, with crowded streets full of motorbikes, tuk-tuks, transport vans, and cars. It was not a city made for walkers, with broken, crumbling sidewalks (when there were sidewalks), no crosswalks, and no culture of yielding to pedestrians. The air was full of fumes so much so that my throat would start to hurt walking down main roads in town. It was hot – a dry heat – and everything was concrete. But it was also totally awesome! People were friendly – many speaking a helpful amount of English – our first peeks at the temples looked amazing, and the food was pl
